job_title: Student Support Specialist in Martinsburg, WV
pros: Great management, nice work environment. Satisfying work.
cons: Low pay to start at first.

pros: Good job for a stay at home mom, as advertised. If that stay at home mom is good at sales. Like really good. The people who tend to do well at this college are people who already have a following on social media.
cons: You have to meet your numbers, or they will fire you. It’s also not like most sales positions where they will give you leads to call, you generally have to create your own leads unless you start to make connections in the company, and then you MIGHT depending on your position and their needs be able to obtain a manifest of people who were previously interested in the college. They do give you a bit of time to meet your numbers, but even if you have previous sales experience, they don’t just hand you leads. You have to find other military spouses on social media and convince them to set an appointment with you. It is what it is 🤷🏼‍♀️ It felt to me like I was bugging people, I also got blasted in several Facebook pages with 50,000+ members for just doing my job at the college Job is not for the weak

job_title: Admission Outreach Coordinator in Washington, DC
pros: There are no pros to this position/company
cons: The most toxic and illegal environment ever. It is an MLM (or pyramid scheme) parading as a for-profit online college. Their certificates are useless. The management is not too different from a sorority, with hundreds of women forming cliques within their ranks. Their diversity is next to non-existent. We were only paid for 4 hours a day...But we were expected to work more than that in order to meet their precious goals...So we worked off the clock with no compensation. They force us to create a fake Facebook profile and harass strangers in our territories to sign up for Martinsburg College. When my husband's grandmother passed away, I was not given any time off to help the family. They said since I was a part-time employee, I already had time off... STAY AWAY from this group. Their product is illegal, they've been sued multiple times, and they treat their staff horribly. STAY AWAY.

review_title: MLM is disguise as working in higher education
job_title: Admissions Outreach Coordinator in Martinsburg, WV
pros: Flexible hours and work schedule.
cons: Very sales driven, and metric driven

job_title: Admissions Outreach Manager in Martinsburg, WV
pros: Good peers to work with
cons: Given more workload with no pay, and no consistent policies or procedures, upper management doesn't care about anyone but themselves because the truth is, everyone is in fear of losing their positions. There are unrealistic metrics being implemented and a lack of support from upper management to give resources for this issue. The culture is toxic and it starts with the CEO. You will never be valued for what you are worth at this business.

job_title: Admissions Outreach Manager in Dallas, TX
pros: Family oriented and supportive staff

job_title: Admissions Outreach Coordinator in Martinsburg, WV

job_title: Admissions Outreach Coordinator in Charleston, WV

pros: I was able to stay home and work while still caring for my two small kids.
cons: A lot of meetings and protocols are changed often so you never know what’s right or wrong to say to potential students.

pros: Remote work, benefits for full time employees, set schedule
cons: Working until 11pm a few nights per week

review_title: It’s a decent place. Just need higher pay.
pros: Work from home. Flexible hours. Never have to call people. Some of my coworkers are amazing. I actually snagged a great manager. You get one free program to take.
cons: THE PAY. Can’t work over your set hours. Even when doing checkins, replying to people.I’m not an overly positive person and I feel like my team doesn’t like me. Meeting goal is stressful.

job_title: Admissions Outreach Coordinator in Martinsburg, WV
pros: flexible, work from home, no childcare required, part-time, starter position, can lead to growth
cons: work requires you to be independent at times

pros: Flexibility, team environment, great starting position

pros:

Remote 
Room for growth

review_title: Min wage job at a scam company
job_title: Admissions Outreach Coordinator in Phoenix, AZ
pros: You can work remotely, that is all.
cons: High pressure sales job that pays minimum wage, you are scamming people on Facebook using a fake FB account, required to work 5 days a week even though you are only a part time employee working 20 hours per week. The company is not reputable, and neither are its business practices.

pros:
Flexible
Work from home
Easy
cons:
Clique-y 
Not much room for growth (they promote friends rather than based on job performance)
Not good work-life balance
Very MLM-like atmosphere.. "I LOVE my job" ,,,,,

pros: None, this place is horrible.
cons: When I first started working for them I wondered why everyone was female. Literally EVERYONE. All of their employees are women, all of their managers etc. Is this some kind of cult…? What is going on here? It’s run like a sorority, they all expect you to be so “positive and relatable” and talk about how you love coffee and love your kids and being a military spouse blah blah blah. The pay is low for all the work you put in and management doesn’t listen or care about their employees, they just care about making money. My friend actually said to me that it seemed like a pyramid scheme and in a way it kind of is. Worst part of all is how they lie to you about how you’re not gonna be faulted for not hitting your goals, when in reality if you don’t meet them you’re instantly fired. Toxic work environment that they try to cover up with their fake “positivity” and “building rapport”. My advice? Don’t work here, don’t go to school here, not worth the time and trouble.

job_title: Outreach Coordinator in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: No childcare policy and work from home
cons: This job will micromanage and place unrealistic demands on you. Turnover is quick because they fire fast!

job_title: Admissions Outreach Coordinator in Martinsburg, WV
pros: Flexible schedule, self motivating and freedom, fun and great teams to work with.
cons: Pay is not enough and employees are under appreciated.

review_title: MLM minus the commission, tbh. Waste of time.
pros: Coworkers are awesome people, you can form new connections with people in your community
cons: They tell you to work 40 hours a week, but expect you to go above and beyond in order to reach “goals”, meaning working 50+ Hours a week and only getting paid for 40. Management REFUSES to listen to their employees when we tell them why we struggle with certain things. They think back to their time in our position (10-30 years ago, not recently at all), and think they know everything about it, as if people and times haven’t changed. They don’t offer any benefits, as they assume you’ll get coverage through your spouse in the military, so when they retire from the service, you’re sh*t out of luck (they mostly only hire military spouses so they don’t have to cover extra costs like that), AND they don’t care about COMPLETELY RUINING your reputation in your area. The job is to recruit people to go to the school, which nobody wants to attend because it’s known all over social media as a scam, and people go around to everyone all over town/base and spread bad things about you in order to get people to avoid you online. Would not recommend.

job_title: Admissions Outreach Coordinator in San Antonio, TX
pros: Hours are very flexible with the ability to work anytime between 8am-10pm.
cons: Pay is crap, and company feels like a start up. No PTO and lots of emphasis on meeting quotas.

job_title: Data Entry Clerk in Fort Irwin, CA
pros: great pay and understanding of schedule
cons: alot of time on the phone

job_title: Admissions Representative in Vero Beach, FL
pros: Lifelong connections made with fellow team members.
cons:
Literally the worst position I have ever had. Sales environment with metrics driven performance evaluations. Predatory recruiting practices. 60+ hour work weeks to be a management-pet that meets/exceeds goals. 

This is a for profit institution using mostly military spouses to prey on their own community. The recruiting practices and "training" they provide brainwashes the reps to believing the programs actually benefit people. They don't. The career fields these programs are claiming to prepare the student for need MUCH more education and experience that these programs will not provide.

job_title: Admissions Outreach Coordinator in Dallas, TX

cons: its basically a MLM except you get a biweekly paycheck

pros: Great management, opportunities for career growth, close team bonds, positive virtual work space.

job_title: Admissions Outreach Coordinator in Martinsburg, WV
pros: Stay at home, no commute
cons: Lots of meetings, low pay

review_title: Aggressive Recruiting Tactics for a Poorly Run School
pros: Gained a couple friends, salary pay.
cons: You must stalk and cold message military spouses and con them out of their education benefits for a useless certificate program. MC doesn't really offer degrees. If you do not meet the quota set for you, you will be fired immediately. Unless you become buddy-buddy with your manager, they will belittle you to the entire group. Good luck!

job_title: Student Admissions Representative in Martinsburg, WV
pros: Love it, such a positive direct leadership team
cons: Upper management is a little removed - doesn't really understand the requirements they put on their staff

pros: Stay at home, no phone work, all social media based
cons: More for military based families who need a part time job

pros: Work from home, good pay
cons: Toxic management, always working, drama

pros: You get to meet new people and become very popular in the military community.
cons:
First, Martinsburg college tells their employees to write GOOD/5 star reviews for Glassdoor. So... thread lightly. 

This college is ran by women who are very superficial and demanding. There is absolutely no work life balance or area to promote within the college, zero fairness and benefits. I guess since they think you’re a military spouse you don’t need any of those. the turnover for employees staying after 90 days is absolutely ridiculous. You are pressured to enroll people into school. Your work space (Facebook) is CONSTANTLY watched for error and used to make post and messages. The money isn’t worth the DAILY struggle of being pressure, overworked and tired. If you don’t make goal, good luck.

pros: You may have some decent coworkers. Unfortunately, the good ones leave and have left for better opportunities. As such, the staff left are the ones who have become the best at scheming, manipulating, and putting others down in attempt to reassert their positions. Financial aid assistance is laughable at best. Have single handedly heard her speak disparagingly abut every past person in the company, including ownership. Have heard the “leadership” team cursing during staff on boarding, speak terribly about good former leaders, and put down current staff. Not a good environment.
cons: Please see above. A very toxic cycle of taking military spouse grant money. There are truly so many that it’s sad. I’ve seen so many good leaders leave. So many good colleagues quit.

job_title: Admissions Representative in Junction City, KS
pros: Management is very understanding with time off. Rewards are given based on merits. Bonuses in the form of Amazon Gift Cards are given for extra projects/work done. Don’t work over 40 hours. After a successful 90 day evaluation a $5k annual raise is given.
cons: Requires employee to be self motivated as the position is remote and requires you to seek out military spouses to further their education. Which sometimes is met with negativity.

pros: I love that I get to help change lives! I love working with such amazing, motivated people!❤️ I couldn’t ask for better co-works! They’re always so willing to help out if I even have any questions within my position. There is always so much room to grow in the college as well which is something super important to me.
cons:
Everyone is in different areas, so you only have opportunities to meet co-workers in person a couple times a year. 
This position is very gratifying, but also demanding at some times.

review_title: Great place to learn a lot of different skills!
pros:
Opportunity for growth.
Ability to learn as much as you want if you are willing to make the effort and wear many hats. 
The College offers a range of programs that are great for young students entering into academics as well as older professionals who want to enhance their current credentials.
cons: It is a small organization so if you are not used to that environment it may take a while to navigate successfully.

pros: The company is great, the directors are very sweet and helpful and will do what they can to help you succeed
cons: It’s a sales job, you’re pulled in 100 different directions and there’s no job security or benefits. Very high turnover rate.

pros: Fully remote position. If consistently meeting goals this job does not require a full 40 hour work week.
cons: Poor management. Upper management only cares about goal. Limited program options. Target market is military spouses. The college has a negative connotation, sometimes can be difficult to recruit students. VERY high turnover rate.

pros: There really aren't any pros except that you can work from home
cons: Very inexperienced management teams, Micromanaging, Company doesn't provide any benefits or time off. Run by women who are very superficial and catty. It is literally a popularity game.

pros: Work from home....that is it.
cons: No balance. You are are always working. The management team threatens you. When you quit people still call you to get help for school.
